discussion.content:
AB
Convergence = Failure_Detection_Time + Event_Propagation_Time + SPF_Run_Time + RIB_FIB_Update_Time

questions.question_text: You are designing a network to support data, voice and video. Which two main factors will you address to improve network convergence? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: RR by default doens't do next-hop self , so next-hop should be persisted from PE, which is R3 and R4 here.
lars96 is right. D is correct. remember, path selection involves: Prefer the path with the lowest IGP metric to the BGP next hop.

D is correct.
iBGP does not changes nexthop

comments.content: After reviewing my previous comment. I retract C is not correct. A is fine.

discussion.content:
C should be correct.
Note R5 and R6 are RR while the rest are clients. 
The dotted lines are the iBGP peers. So R8 learns about 10.1.1.0/24 from RR_R5 while R7 from RR_R6

choices.B: The next hop for 10.1.1.0/24 on R7 is R5 and the next hop for R8 is R6.
choices.A: The next hop for 10.1.1.0/24 on R7 is R8 and the next hop for R8 is R7.
choices.D: The next hop for 10.1.1.0/24 on R7 is R3 and the next hop for R8 is R4.
choices.C: The next hop for 10.1.1.0/24 on R7 is R6 and the next hop for R8 is R5.

questions.question_text:
Refer to the exhibit. In this BGP design, what is the next hop for 10.1.1.0/24 on R8 and R7?
//IMG//

discussion.content:
A
Single-topology doesn't prevent ipv4 communications

choices.D: All routers except R2 are reachable through IPv4.
choices.E: R3 advertises the link from R3-R2 to R1, R4 and R5 only.
choices.C: Loopback reachability between all routers for IPv4 is lost.
choices.B: R2 receives an IPv6 default route from R3.
choices.A: Only R3 and R2 have IPv4 and IPv6 reachability.

discussion.content:
A summary route (ospf) will take by default the lowest metric of the sumarized routes.
https://learningnetwork.cisco.com/s/question/0D53i00000KsxCG/cost-ospf-summary-route
The diagram in the question shows thet B is sending a summary, so it would be advertsed to A with metric 10.

questions.question_text:
Refer to the exhibit. Will traffic sourced from router A and destined for a host on network 10.1.1.0/24 always take the optimal path to that host?
//IMG//

choices.E: It depends on the routing protocol.
choices.A: No, if router A chooses to forward traffic destined to a host on the 10.1.1.0/24 network to router B, it will take a less than optimal path to reach its destination.
choices.B: Yes, router A has enough information to always direct traffic to router C when forwarding traffic to a host on the 10.1.1.0/24 network.
choices.D: It doesn't matter which path to a host on 10.1.1.0/24 router A chooses, through router B or router C, since they are equal in cost.
choices.C: Yes, router B will forward the traffic towards 10.1.1.0/24 correctly, if router A chooses that path.

questions.question_text: Your design plan includes mutual redistribution of two OSPF networks at multiple locations, with connectivity to all locations in both networks. How is this accomplished without creating routing loops?

choices.D: Use route maps on the ASBRs to filter routes with tags so they are not redistributed.
choices.A: Use route maps on the ASBRs to allow only internal routes to be redistributed.
choices.B: Use route maps on the ASBRs to allow internal and external routes to be redistributed.
choices.C: Use route maps on the ASBRs to set tags for redistributed routes.
